Award.AwardTitle: Global solutions of semilinear and quasilinear dispersive equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will study questions related to global existence and long-term dynamics of smooth solutions of certain evolution equations. More precisely, the PI will consider several quasilinear models, such as the Euler-Maxwell system, the Euler-Poisson system, and the irrotational water wave problem in dimensions 2 and 3. The main problems to be considered have to do with the global stability of certain equilibrium solutions of these equations. The PI will also continue his work on the global existence of Schrodinger maps and other spin field systems, in the case of large data.


The equations considered in the project describe physical phenomena, such as plasma evolutions, ferromagnetic models, and fluid dynamics, and their relevance is often verified numerically. The PI proposes to study the solutions of these equations rigorously, and recover quantitative and qualitative information about their behavior as mathematical theorems. An important aspect of this proposal is to support the training of graduate students and to foster collaborations with researchers in related fields, such as Physics and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

 

The PI and his collaborators studied questions related to global existence and long-term dynamics of smooth solutions of certain nonlinear dispersive equations. These equations describe physical phenomena, such as plasma evolutions and fluid dynamics, and the goal of the PI was to study the solutions of these equations rigorously, and recover quantitative and qualitative information about their behavior as mathematical theorems.

More precisely, the PI and his collaborators considered several quasilinear models, such as the Euler--Maxwell plasma model, the Euler--Poisson system, the irrotational water wave problem, and two-fluid models in dimensions 2 and 3. The main results proved as part of the project were:

1. global regularity for small initial data of the full two-fluid Euler-Maxwell system in three dimensions (in collaboration with Y. Guo and B. Pausader);

2. global regularity of the one-fluid Euler-Maxwell system in two dimensions (in collaboration with Y. Deng and B. Pausader);

3. the absence of "no-splash" singularities for two-fluid models in two dimensions (in collaboration with C. Fefferman and V. Lie);

4. global regularity and nonlinear scattering of capillary water waves in two dimensions (in collaboration with F. Pusateri);

5. global regularity of the full gravity-capillary water waves system in three dimensions (in collaboration with Y. Deng, B. Pausader, and F. Pusateri).

 

Related problems were also studied independently by some of the students of the PI, in particular leading to a robust theory of global regularity for many physical water wave models.

 

Broader impacts:

 

Several graduate students of the PI (Matthew Hernandez, Yu Zhang, Xuecheng Wang, Yu Deng, and Fan Zheng) were supported at various times to work on the project. Two post-doctoral fellows (Xuecheng Wang and Huy Nguyen) were also supported in part in the last two years to work on problems related to the project.

The PI teaches a graduate course in Mathematics every year at Princeton University. He integrated some of the results supported by the grant, at a slightly simplified level and including suitable background, into his advanced graduate courses in Spring 2015, Spring 2016, and Spring 2017.

 

The PI delivered many lectures at national and international conferences and summer schools, on the research problems supported by the grant. For example, he delivered two lectures at the Seventeenth Riviere-Fabes Symposium on Analysis and PDE, University of Minnesota, April 2014; 3+1 lectures at the workshop Harmonic Analysis Methods in Dispersive PDEs Hausdorff Research Institute for Mathematics, Bonn (Germany), June 2014; one lecture at the conference Harmonic Analysis and Partial Differential Equations: Recent Developments and Future Directions (in honor of C. E. Kenig), University of Chicago, September 2014; and one lecture at the MSRI program New Challenges in PDE: Deterministic Dynamics and Randomness in High and Infinite Dimensional Systems, October 2015.
